clean_story:
Facts over guesses. Proof over belief.


"Evidence" comes from the Latin evidentia—meaning "clear to see. " In science, it’s the data that turns ideas into knowledge.


Science isn’t about who shouts loudest or who’s been around longest. It’s about what can be measured, tested, and repeated.
Imagine baking cookies. If you change the recipe but don’t write down what you did, you’ll never know why they burned—or why they turned out perfect.
Evidence works the same way.
A scientist claims, "This plant cures fever. " Without tests on real patients, comparisons to placebos, or repeated trials, it’s just a story.
Good evidence is specific.
In 1928, Alexander Fleming noticed mold killing bacteria in a petri dish. He didn’t just say, "Mold is useful. " He recorded the mold type (Penicillium), tested its effects, and shared the method so others could verify it.
That’s how guesses become penicillin.
Bad evidence?
Anecdotes ("My grandpa smoked and lived to 100!") ignore the thousands who didn’t.
Cherry-picked data (showing only the results that fit) is like judging a whole orchestra by one out-of-tune violin.
The strongest evidence predicts.
Einstein’s math predicted light would bend near the sun—later confirmed during a 1919 eclipse.
When evidence contradicts a theory, scientists don’t cling to the theory.
They ask: "What did we miss?"


Peer review.
Replication.
The slow, unglamorous work of ruling out mistakes.
Because in science, the truth isn’t what you want—it’s what the evidence will let you keep.
